Award.AwardTitle: Bacterial Light Sensing by Photoactive Yellow Protein

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Biological signaling processes help organisms respond to changes in their environment and to ensure proper regulation of their internal processes. Biological signaling starts when a receptor protein is activated by interaction with a signal. Two important fields of research in biological signaling are (i) the structural and chemical properties of isolated receptor proteins and (ii) the identification of signaling pathways in living cells and organisms. This project will use a bacterial photoreceptor called photoactive yellow protein (PYP) as a model system to obtain a direct link between these two research areas. Until recently, bacterial photoreceptors were thought to be specialized proteins present only in a small number of phototrophic bacteria. Unexpectedly, bacterial genome sequencing projects have revealed that many chemotrophs also contain photosensory proteins. This project will explore this developing area of bacterial photosensing. The research will explore the function of PYPs in a number of very different bacterial organisms, will examine the signal transduction chain associated with PYP, and will uncover which of the structural and chemical changes that are known to occur upon the light activation of PYP are required for signaling in the living bacterial cell.

Broader impacts. Fundamental aspects of bacterial signaling will be explored, particularly the role of partial protein unfolding as a novel signaling mechanism. An increased understanding of biological signaling will have implications for a range of relevant areas, including biotechnology. Undergraduate students from underrepresented minorities will be actively involved in the proposed research. In addition, a series of presentations in the successful "Stillwater Science Caf√©" will be organized. These presentations will be aimed at elementary school students and involve interactive presentations and hands-on demonstrations by OSU faculty members on their current research in the biological life sciences. This will increase understanding of and appreciation for science in elementary school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacteria contain proteins that function similar to the light-sensitive proteins in the human eye that allow us to see. These proteins are called photoreceptors. This project studied two aspects of such bacterial photoreceptors.

Aspect 1: Recent work has revealed that unexpectedly many bacteria contain photoreceptor proteins. In almost ll of these cases it remains entirely unknown how light affects the behavior and properties of the bacteria containing these photoreceptors. We found and reported various lines of evidence that in many cases bacteria use these photoreceptors to decide if the bacteria will live as single cells of if they will live as a compact layer of bacteral cells called a biofilm. Our results indicate that many different bacteria use photorecepors to regulate biofilm formation based on the absence or presence of light. This result is of potential medical relevance, since biofilm formation is involved in various bacterial infections. 

Aspect 2: Proteins are able to very efficiently and effectively perform a very wide array of different functions in all living organisms. Many fundamental questions remain regarding the fundamental mechanisms that allow proteins to achieve this stunning feat. Despite prolongued and intense studies by many research groups, these questions have proven very hard to answer. Photorecetors offer a unique opportunity in trying to address the molecular mechanisms invovled in protein function because their function is light triggered. Therefore, their function can be started by a brief flash of light, and the progress in the function of the protein can be studied using various spectroscopic techiques. These approaches are only applicable to proteins that have a function which is light-triggered. Two key findings from our work are that (i) a previously unrecognized type of interaction called ionic hydrogen bonding is important for determining the functional properties of proteins, and (ii) a novel spectroscopic technique called Raman Optical Activity spectroscopy provides a powerful approach to study previously inaccessible but funcionally important fatures of proteins by allowing experimental determination in the degree to which molecules inside the protein are distorted.

This project also supported a series of educational opportunities. first, a substantial number of undergraduate students worked in classical laboratory research internships on thie project, allowing these students to gain hands on experience in widely applicable techniques in protein science and molecular genetics research. Second, the project allowed multiple "Born to do Science" outreach events to be organized in which midel school students meet and their caregivers with professional scientists and get to learn about the research projects that these scientists are performing. Third, substantial progress was made in changing large undergraduate student laboratory courses, so that these courses involve exciting and authentic research. Currently, this aspect of the project has succeded in allowing undergraduate students to contribute to bacterial genmics research while taking courses. This approach of course-embedded authentic research is a highly promising way to increase student persistence, performance, and quality of science learning,
